results.title: Ladies of Lockington
results.brief_description: Meet the ladies who are at the heart of Lockington. These passionate and committed women get things done. They network, coordinate, manage and harness the talent that is available to them to improve and enhance the quality of life for all the families of Lockington and surrounding districts.

results.title: Below Beechworth
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description: Starting at the Burke Museum, local guide Dan Goonan, gives us a short history lesson about the gold rush days of Beechworth. We then follow Goonan as he takes us on a tour of the hidden underground tunnels which remain as a legacy of the Gold Rush. This film explores what lies below Beechworth, the parts you rarely see.

results.title: Living in Locky: The Youth Perspective
results.brief_description: 17 year old Locky local, Emma McInnes interviews a cross section of young people to find out what life in a rural town is really like. What is there to do? What the future holds and the all important question, are there many lookers in Locky?

results.title: Yackandandah music
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Csilla Csongvay, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description: The future stars of the Australian music industry are alive and well and living in Yackandandah. No matter where life takes them, music is sure to play a big part in the lives of these young musicians. From Richard Perso and The Two Girls to the tiny violinists from ‘Violindigo’ the town of Yackandandah supports its emerging artists by providing them a stage at the Shed during the annual Yack Folk Festival.

results.title: ACMI in the regions: Stories from Lockington
results.brief_description: Interviews with residents, groups and business owners of Lockington, Shire of Campaspe. These five short documentaries look at life in Lockington from different perspectives, covering local businesses, the Lockington Living Heritage Complex, a young girl growing up in Lockington, the experiences of a group of women and the Lockington Hotel, where the locals come to meet and enjoy local music at night.

results.title: From Latvia to Beechworth : personal journeys
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description: Beate and Marta immigrated to Australia with their families, changing their lives for ever. Leaving behind their native Latvia both women struggled with acceptance, a new language, new customs and a foreign environment. This film showcases the strength, humour and humanity needed to survive and to flourish in a new land. Inga, her mother Beate and their friend Marta reflect on their lives and traditions, old and new.

results.title: Lockington Living Heritage Complex
results.brief_description: Celebrating and preserving the rich history of Lockington and its surrounding district, the dedicated and hard working volunteers of the Lockington Living Heritage Complex take us on a tour of the complex with the highlight being ‘The Big Shed’ which at 106 metres houses a restored Melbourne tram and the first ever pop top caravan, hand built in Lockington.

results.title: My Omeo: A Short History
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: Jeff Cooper is a guardian of all things great about Omeo and its chequered history. His role within the community is not only as a custodian of the local records but also as a passionate tour guide of the Omeo Historic Park and local gold fields. The Park contains 5 heritage-listed buildings that are believed to be some of the most intact and original in Australia. Jeff believes Omeo is the last bastion of self-funded retirement and despite losing his home and livestock in the 2003 bushfires, wouldn’t live anywhere else in the world.

results.title: Lockington Film Premiere: ACMI in the Regions
results.brief_description: In July 2008, the ACMI Content Development crew spent four days in Lockington and produced five short documentary films. The premier screening of these short films took place on the 15th of January 2009, on a hot and humid Thursday evening in the Lockington & District Community Centre. Over 200 locals joined Tony Sweeney and Kim Montgomery, from ACMI, and Louise Ross, a local and chief community organiser, to showcase the films and celebrate the stories that make Lockington a thriving and unique regional town. This film of the premiere screenings captures the excitement of the locals with a red carpet arrival for all the guests, the handing out of DVDs to all individuals that were involved in the project and finally vox pops from the audience members as they share with us their appreciation and pride for the films.
